meta.title: Anthropologies and Futures: Researching Emerging and Uncertain Worlds
meta.author: Juan Francisco Salazar, Sarah Pink, Andrew Irving, Johannes Sjöberg

parts.title: Futures Anthropologies Manifesto
parts.body: The "Futures Anthropologies Manifesto" is an effort by the European Association of Social Anthropologists to reimagine anthropology's role in addressing future challenges. Written at a 2014 conference, this 10-point manifesto highlights how anthropologists can embrace uncertainty, transcend traditional boundaries, and engage with complex futures through collaboration and innovation. It calls for a shift from focusing solely on the past to also considering potential futures, emphasizing a move towards participatory and ethical interventions. This approach seeks to maintain anthropology's critical core while opening it up to a more active role in contemporary world-making.

parts.title: Imaginative Spaces and Temporal Connections
parts.body:
Imaginative Spaces and Connections

This section delves into how our imaginative faculties create connections between images, like seeing two photographs and constructing a narrative that fills the gaps. Aristotle's idea that thinking combines imagination and judgment suggests a narrative bridge built through our capacity to associate events over time. This process not only involves creative associations across space and time but also points to how events become metaphorically linked in our minds.

Temporal Connections and Everyday Decisions

The focus shifts to how simple everyday decisions, like turning left or right, can intertwine with large-scale events, impacting lives and creating a complex interplay between personal actions and global events. This highlights anthropology's challenge in understanding the interconnectedness of people's futures and global scales. The chapter underscores the need for an empirical and ethnographic approach to grasp how actions define possibilities and constraints of lives across the globe.

Revisiting Sandra's Story

Returning to the images, the narrative focuses on Sandra Kyagaba, an HIV+ activist in Uganda, holding a picture of herself from September 11, 2001. Her narrative captures the temporal interplay of personal hardship and global crises, symbolizing how individual experiences are part of a broader historical context. Sandra's story highlights how personal narratives reshape over time, intertwining with global events, emphasizing that even life histories can involve remembering and rethinking past events from the vantage point of unforeseeable futures.

parts.title: Imagination, Memory, and Global Events Connection
parts.body: Andrew Irving discusses the role of imagination and memory in constructing narratives by examining two photos related to September 11, 2001. One shows Sandra Kyagaba, an HIV+ Ugandan activist, who holds a picture of her younger self, taken on 9/11, signifying a temporal interplay with her past and future. The other photo captures the exact moment of the second plane hitting the World Trade Center, illustrating the global impacts on individual lives. He explores the embodiment and decision-making processes individuals go through daily, such as simple decisions like turning left or right, and how these actions connect individual lives to broader global events. Sandra's life journey, detailed through a tracking method called "Life Journeys Method," highlights how personal histories entwine with larger narratives, bridging past and future. This method involves physically retracing life paths and noting new memories and thoughts that arise. Through Sandra's story, which moves from a comfortable childhood to facing HIV infection, Irving emphasizes the ethnographic connection between actions, contingency, and future. This narrative approach considers how ordinary events and decisions intertwine with larger geopolitical happenings, illustrating the ethnographic and anthropological avenues available for understanding contemporary global connectedness and future possibilities.

parts.title: Sandra's Turning Point: From Despair to Activism
parts.body: After Sandra discovered she was HIV positive, her situation grew worse as her late boyfriend’s family took her daughter, fearing Sandra’s impending death. Sandra felt devastated and had given up hope until she heard Major Rubaramira Ruranga on the radio share how he publicly declared his HIV status and now assists those diagnosed. Inspired, Sandra contacted the major, who helped restore her faith and become an HIV/AIDS activist herself. On 11 September 2001, while attending a women’s conference and sharing her story, Sandra met Emily Bass, an organizer and journalist from New York. Emily comforted Sandra but wasn’t aware of the bad news that Sandra's CD4 count was critically low. This unexpected intersection later led to Emily’s family deciding to fund Sandra’s antiretroviral medication, saving her life, highlighting how life’s contingency can radically alter futures. This narrative exemplifies how the introduction of antiretroviral treatments revolutionized HIV/AIDS lives, often depending on geopolitical status. Despite having life-saving treatments in the West, African countries faced economic barriers. Sandra’s experience underscores the disparity and how small decisions, like turning left, could lead to monumental changes in life.

parts.title: Narratives of Autistic Futures: Insights and Advocacy
parts.body:
Contributions of Autistic Narratives in Envisioning Futures

The Autistic Self Advocacy Network (ASAN) plays a vital role in expanding autistic futures through their publication "Loud Hands: Autistic People, Speaking". Bascom highlights how autistic individuals often face "abuse and silencing" frequently heard as "Quiet hands" in education sectors. "Loud Hands" signifies resisting these barriers by communicating in inherently autistic ways and asserting the dignity of autistic voices. This project aligns with creative visions focused on a "radically inclusive future" fueled by increasing numbers and engagement within the autistic community and its supporters.

Parental and First-Person Accounts in Disability Narratives

Parental memoirs, such as Ron Suskind’s "Life Animated," offer profound insights into familial journeys with autism, showcasing unique communication pathways through memorized Disney scripts. These narratives grant autistic individuals and their families alternative futures filled with acceptance and kinship. Similarly, first-person accounts like Temple Grandin’s and Donna Williams’ writings have sparked wider awareness, encouraging people with ASD to articulate their stories, thus shaping future perceptions of autism and disability.

Exploring Multiple Futures through Literature and Networks

Works by autistic advocates contribute to societal understanding by bridging the gap between narratives and numbers. These narratives offer a fresh lens on future-making that challenges mainstream disability discourses. With the support of expanding disability publics, they aim for a future where autism is embraced within society as a "new normal," strongly backed by powerful narratives and demographic realities. Thus, envisioning autistic futures becomes a dynamic process intertwined with ongoing political and narrative evolution.

parts.title: Pyrenean Rewilding and Future Ethnographies
parts.body:
Pyrenean Rewilding and Ontological Landscapes: A Future Ethnographic Approach

The Pyrenean pastoralists face conflicts due to the re-introduction of bears and wolves. Conservationists argue for rewilding to combat biodiversity loss during the Anthropocene, a new geological epoch marked by significant human impact on the Earth, including global climate change and biological extinction. This scenario places humans in a shadow of potential catastrophe. Anthropology reaches beyond being just a witness to present issues, urging engagement with future challenges of the Anthropocene. A future-oriented approach incorporates both ethnographic field subjects and state institutions to engage actively with future worldmaking. In the context of the French Pyrenees, tensions arise between traditional pastoralists and modernization efforts advocating for eco-tourism and less human-predator conflict. Ethnographic research in the Pyrenees highlights conflicts between 'traditional' pastoralists and ecologists aiming for landscape rewilding. Conservationists envision a future where these species help maintain ecosystem balance, but pastoralists argue this threatens their way of life. This conflict is analyzed through ethnographic questioning—allowing locals to express their projections into a future world, reflecting both environmental and socio-political challenges.

parts.title: Amal's Navigating Transnational Custody and Resilience
parts.body: Amal, a woman dealing with the kidnapping of her daughter Isra, faced legal barriers and complex interpersonal dynamics. Despite the attempts to engage Danish authorities, she found little support due to jurisdictional limitations. Her journey highlights the challenges of navigating international laws governing child custody involving multiple nations and cultures. Instead of direct actions that might oppose her family's wishes, Amal turned to patience and faith as strategies, showcasing a commitment to sabr – an Islamic virtue of patience and reliance on God's plan. This approach was necessary not only to potentially reunite with her daughter but to maintain essential familial relationships and support systems. Within this framework of enduring hardships, Amal integrated religious practices into her coping mechanism, demonstrating how digital technologies provided an avenue to maintain connections and express yearnings for reunification. Amal's interactions via digital platforms reveal layers of her lived realities and dreams, where technology served as a tool to broadcast her emotional turmoil and hope. Meanwhile, the text explores how the imaginal realm distills visions and emotions beyond conventional space-time, providing a spiritual perspective on navigating the uncertainties around the future. Ultimately, Amal's story is both a testament to resilience and a critique of institutional inefficacy in transnational familial disputes.

parts.title: Exploring Futures Anthropology in Antarctica
parts.body: In this chapter, Salazar introduces an approach to ethnographic research focused on exploring Antarctica as a site for understanding future human habitation in extreme environments. His work involves 1. The making of a documentary film, "Nightfall on Gaia," which acts as an example of how futures anthropology can be creatively pursued. This film uses a mix of fictional and real elements to engage with the speculative potential of life on the Antarctic continent. 2. His research emphasizes how transient communities in Antarctica perceive their environment, charting future possibilities through a lens of anticipatory and speculative narratives. This approach highlights how humans and other species come together in this unique environment, raising crucial questions about collaboration and habitation. 3. Salazar’s work illustrates a method of "speculative fabulation," a concept inspired by Donna Haraway, which suggests a creative form of narrating the possible as a method for discussing real-world implications of extreme environmental conditions and future socialities. This involves envisioning Antarctic worlds not just as they are, but as they could be, embracing a future-oriented anthropology that embodies hope and imagination.

parts.title: Understanding Future Perceptions through Ethno Science Fiction
parts.body: The chapter discusses how applying ethno science fiction as an ethnographic method can help understand how British youth perceive future environmental threats. This is illustrated through a film project where James, living in a flood-prone neighborhood, imagines his future using improvised phone calls to his future selves, exploring themes of climate change, social transformation, and personal aspirations. Ethno science fiction combines ethnographic research with creative practices like improvisation, allowing people to critically engage with scientific predictions. It challenges traditional methods by focusing on speculative elements to trigger imagination and possibilities. The approach connects fiction with practice, helping individuals explore potential futures and how these visions impact present understanding. Influenced by Jean Rouch's ethnofictions and Peter Watkins' documentary dramas, the method reflects a process of dreaming and improvisation that draws on real-life experiences and utopias. It allows participants to navigate their lives, balancing the dystopian and utopian visions through a liminal space, which helps in charting personal paths. Thus, it offers a distinct tool to capture individual perspectives and possible futures in response to societal and environmental challenges.

parts.title: Exploring Future Imaginations of Migrants
parts.body: Alex is conducting research with Egyptian migrants in Milan to explore how their perceptions of the future influence their narratives of lived experiences. An important focus is how the future is seen through dreams, hopes, and fears, becoming tangible in their daily actions and stories. The future gives them a sense of direction and is crucial for redefining who they are. One participant, Mahmud, starts imagining a better future when his legal status changes, allowing him to work and dream of returning home seen through his imagination. These dreams align with his daily dedication to build a better future, making hardships like the Mediterranean crossing meaningful. Alex uses various methods, including creative workshops and ethnofiction filmmaking, to show how the imagined future takes form and influences the present actions of migrants. These methods reveal the significance of imaginative processes in their lives and challenge static ethnographic methodologies by creatively engaging with imaginative possibilities.

parts.title: Remix and Future-Oriented Anthropology
parts.body: Remix is seen as a way to rethink anthropological practice by drawing on cool strategies like integration and generating dialogue among various disciplines. This approach applies concepts from hip-hop culture to academia, suggesting that "remix methodology" can transform how we understand the world by crafting new cultural meanings through sampling and hybridization. This method emphasizes creative agency and encourages collaboration across different disciplines and cultures. During remixing, original elements are recontextualized, producing nuanced meanings with possible connections. This process encourages adaptive thinking and challenges static scientific models by incorporating multiple perspectives and reflecting on the temporary and evolving nature of knowledge. Scholars are thus encouraged to embrace a "third space" for innovative thinking between private and work life, symbolizing a space for collaborations that consider creative and speculative aspects of future possibilities. By integrating remix practices, anthropologists are nudged to appreciate imaginative methodologies that can heavily influence future-oriented studies, inviting transdisciplinary research opportunities. This invitation urges us to engage in public anthropology and consider how our insights can not only reflect but intervene in shaping possible futures, essentially acting as catalyst for significant social change.
